message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The foul-smelling discharge from one side of the nose without any history of trauma, tenderness or abnormality on X-ray suggests the most likely cause is a nasal foreign body. Bilateral maxillary sinusitis would have shown an abnormality on X-ray and would not have unilateral symptoms. Septal hematoma would cause swelling and pain, and a nasal tumor is rare in a child.

We refer to the Mayo Clinic website for help. The foul-smelling discharge and the fact that it is only coming from one nostril suggests a nasal foreign body. The lack of tenderness on palpation and normal X-ray image of the sinuses also supports this diagnosis. Bilateral maxillary sinusitis would likely present with more systemic symptoms, while a septal hematoma or nasal tumor would have different clinical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest the most likely cause is a nasal foreign body causing localized irritation, infection, and resulting in foul-smelling discharge from one nostril. The absence of tenderness on palpation and abnormality on X-ray rules out other options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of foul-smelling discharge oozing out from one nostril in a young child with no history of trauma raised suspicion for a nasal foreign body. The X-ray image showed no abnormality, which is consistent with a foreign body that is not radiopaque. Bilateral maxillary sinusitis would typically present with bilateral symptoms, fever, and tenderness over the sinus areas. Septal hematoma and nasal tumor are rare diagnoses and would require further evaluation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of foul-smelling discharge from one side of the nose along with no tenderness on palpation or abnormality on X-ray suggest a nasal foreign body. Bilateral maxillary sinusitis would cause symptoms in both nostrils, septal hematoma would cause tenderness on palpation, and a nasal tumor is unlikely in a young child without other symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of foul-smelling discharge from one side of the nose suggest a nasal foreign body. Bilateral maxillary sinusitis would cause symptoms on both sides, and there is no tenderness over the facial bones to suggest a hematoma or tumor. The lack of abnormality on X-ray also supports the diagnosis of a foreign body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the foul-smelling discharge from one side of the nose, suggest a nasal foreign body. There is no history of trauma to the nose, but young children often insert items into their noses. The absence of tenderness on palpation or abnormality on an X-ray image of the paranasal sinuses also supports the diagnosis of a nasal foreign body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The foul-smelling discharge on one side of the nose is a common symptom of a nasal foreign body. Other symptoms include unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent sinusitis. Examination and X-ray imaging did not reveal any other abnormalities, making a nasal foreign body the most likely cause. Bilateral maxillary sinusitis would cause discharge from both nostrils and tenderness upon palpation over the sinuses. Septal hematoma and nasal tumor are less likely in a child with no history of trauma and no other accompanying symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. With no trauma history or imaging abnormality, the most likely cause of the foul-smelling discharge is a nasal foreign body. The fact that the discharge is only from one nostril also supports this diagnosis. Bilateral maxillary sinusitis would cause symptoms in both nostrils and would likely show up on imaging. Septal hematoma would cause tenderness on palpation over the nose, which was not found in this case. Nasal tumor is unlikely in a 4-year-old and would require further investigation with imaging or biopsy to confirm.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The foul-smelling discharge from one nostril, with no tenderness on palpation, and normal X-ray images of sinuses suggest a nasal foreign body as the most likely cause. Bilateral maxillary sinusitis would cause symptoms in both nostrils. Septal hematoma would cause tenderness on palpation. Nasal tumors are rare in children and would require further imaging for diagnosis.
